introduction.p: In order to discuss systems of equations like this, it will be convenient for us to have notation for keeping track of multiple numbers at once. Vectors provide us with this notation. In the case of vectors with 2 or 3 entries, there is a strong connection between vector algebra and geometry. This can be very helpful to us as we develop an intuition for vector algebra, even when there are more than 3 entries.

This chapter is devoted to solving systems of linear equations in a systematic way. It begins with an algebraic and computational study, and ends with a conceptual geometric treatment.
In we begin with a brief discussion of systems of linear equations and their solutions.
In we give an introduction to vector and matrix algebra, which will be used throughout the text.
In we will discuss the elimination method for solving systems of equations, and we will learn to write systems of equations in terms of matrices and vectors.
In we will learn the Gaussian elimination and Jordan substitution algorithms, which are fundamental tools for solving systems of equations.
In we will use Gaussian elimination to extract an important property of a matrix: the location of its pivots. We then show how the pivots characterize the number of solutions of a system of equations.
We turn to computational considerations in , where we will discuss how to use Gaussian elimination efficiently on a computer. This will require some background on invertible and elementary matrices, introduced in .
In we will learn how to parameterize the solution set of a system of equations when the system has more than one solution.
In we will discuss the geometry of vectors and linear combinations. This culminates in the notion of a span.
In we will use spans to gain a thorough geometric understanding of a system of equations.

note.p: Understand the eigenvalue problem and its applications.
Understand how to use the Singular Value Decomposition and Principal Component Analysis to solve data-driven problems.
